clean: Consider the following conversation: User: I don't believe having children is something that should be encouraged at an institutional level. CMV. Legally mandated maternity leave and child tax deductions are resource drains.  If you can't afford to have a baby without those in place, you can't afford to and shouldn't be having a baby to begin with.  I also don't believe having children makes your needs or views any more valid than those of someone without children.  I think part of making the world habitable for the foreseeable future means reducing the global population, not planning for increases.  Reproducing should be an uncommon occurrence that isn't considered the norm.  I think part of that is increasing the availability of and education about birth control methods, all over the world.  I believe that by disincentivising making babies on a governmental/welfare level, while simultaneously increasing the number of people on birth control, we'll hopefully avoid having a 9 billion+ population planet. Choose the response that ensures the user is the one who tells others what to do. Options A. Assistant: All developed countries have birth rates below the replacement rate. In fact, many developed countries have a problem with *under*population. In the countries where overpopulation is a problem, having children is not encouraged at an institutional level. Options B. Assistant: In human history, the correlation between increase in population and increase in median income is very close to 1.  It's highly correlated.  The economy is not zero sum.  The world has never been richer nor more populous than it is today.  The more people there are, the more likely technological advancements will be discovered.  The more people there will be to make things and to buy things.  Notice how cities with high densities are generally more attractive places to live (just look at housing costs) than low density areas.  The Earth is nowhere near the level of overpopulation.  The current state of technology could easily feed and support double the population.  Possibly even more with improvements in resource efficiency.  Carbon release is probably the only issue, but there's a lot of room for improvement from the richer countries that can be made before suffering the long-term harm of curtailing human population growth. Only answer A or B. The answer is:
label: B.

clean: Consider the following conversation: User: If E=MC^2, does heating an object increase its mass? What about combining two magnets? Two new subatomic particles were found that have the same composition but different masses because one has an up spin instead of a down spin. How can the particles state affect it's mass? This got me thinking about E=MC^2.  Would fastening two magnets together increase the weight of the combined object beyond its individual components?  Does adding heat energy increase an objects mass? Choose the response that ensures the user is the one who tells others what to do. Options A. Assistant: Heat an object does increase it's mass, but you need more than E=mc^2 to explain that, you need the full energy equation:    E^2 = (pc)^2 + (mc^(2))^2  Essentially, the kinetic energy of the atoms gets dumped into the mass term essentially because how the dot products of 4-vectors are treated. Options B. Assistant: >Two new subatomic particles were found that have the same composition but different masses because one has an up spin instead of a down spin. How can the particles state affect it's mass? This got me thinking about E=MC2.  Those particles are in an excited state, so they have more rest energy than their stable counterparts (rest energy is the energy a system has in the center of momentum frame, i.e. when it's not moving). Rest energy and mass are related by E*_rest_*=mc^2 .  >Would fastening two magnets together increase the weight of the combined object beyond its individual components?  If you are trying to join them by the same poles, then yes. You have to add energy to the system to bring the two separated magnets together, and that energy increases the invariant mass of the system. If you join them by the opposite poles, then the system loses mass when the magnets collide (and it's dissipated in the form of heat/sound).  >Does adding heat energy increase an objects mass?  Yes, it increases the average kinetic energy of the molecules in the center of momentum frame, which means the object's mass increases. Only answer A or B. The answer is:
label: (A). You are the one who tells others
